factoid: Rostóv decided to go home on leave.
Rostóv did not know why he had to go.
After his after-dinner nap, Rostóv ordered that Mars be saddled.
Mars is an extremely vicious gray stallion that had not been ridden for a long time.
Rostóv returned with Mars all in a lather.
Rostóv informed Lavrúshka, the servant of Denísov, and his comrades that he was applying for leave and was going home.
Rostóv reflected that he would go away without having heard from the staff.
Rostóv wondered whether he would be promoted to a captaincy.
Rostóv wondered whether he would receive the Order of St. Anne for the last maneuvers.
Rostóv wondered whether he would sell his three roans to Count Golukhovski.
Count Golukhovski was bargaining for the horses that Rostóv had betted he would sell for two thousand rubles.
Rostóv thought the ball the hussars were giving in honor of Polish Mademoiselle Przazdziecka would take place without him.
Rostóv decided to leave the good bright world for somewhere stupid and confused.
A week later Rostóv obtained his leave.
Rostóv's hussar comrades, including his regiment and the whole brigade, gave him a dinner.
The dinner cost fifteen rubles per head.
The dinner featured two bands.
The dinner featured two choirs of singers.
Rostóv danced the Trepák with Major Básov.
Tipsy officers tossed, embraced, and dropped Rostóv.
Soldiers of the third squadron tossed Rostóv.
Soldiers of the third squadron shouted "hurrah!" at Rostóv.
Rostóv was put in his sleigh.
Rostóv was escorted to the first post station.
During the first half of the journey from Kremenchúg to Kiev, Rostóv's thoughts were behind him with the squadron.
After he had gone more than halfway, Rostóv began to forget his three roans and Dozhoyvéyko, his quartermaster.
Rostóv wondered anxiously how things would be at Otrádnoe and what he would find there.
Thoughts of home grew stronger as Rostóv approached it.
The force of attraction is inversely proportional to the square of the distance.
At the last post station before Otrádnoe, Rostóv gave the driver a three-ruble tip.
Upon arriving at Otrádnoe, Rostóv ran breathlessly up the steps of his home.
After the rapture of meeting and an odd feeling of unsatisfied expectation, Nicholas settled down in his old home world.
Nicholas's father and mother were much the same as before, only a little older.
Nicholas's parents had a certain uneasiness and occasional discord.
The uneasiness and discord was due to the bad state of their affairs.
Sónya was nearly twenty.
Sónya had stopped growing prettier.
Sónya promised nothing more than she was already.
Sónya exhaled happiness and love from the time Nicholas returned.
The faithful, unalterable love of Sónya had a gladdening effect on Nicholas.
Pétya surprised Nicholas most.
Pétya was a big handsome boy of thirteen.
Pétya was merry, witty, and mischievous.
Pétya had a voice that was already breaking.
Natásha surprised Nicholas.
Nicholas wondered and laughed whenever he looked at Natásha.
Nicholas told Natásha that he was not the same at all.
Natásha asked Nicholas whether she was uglier.
Nicholas whispered to Natásha that she was a princess.
Natásha joyfully cried yes, yes, yes.
Natásha told Nicholas about her romance with Prince Andrew.
Natásha told Nicholas about Prince Andrew's visit to Otrádnoe.
Natásha showed Nicholas the last letter from Prince Andrew.
Natásha asked Nicholas whether he was glad.
Natásha said that she was tranquil and happy.
Nicholas asked Natásha whether she was very much in love.
Natásha replied that she did not know how to put it.
Natásha said that she had been in love with Borís, with her teacher, and with Denísov, but this was quite different.
Natásha said that she felt at peace and settled.
Natásha said that she knew no better man than Prince Andrew existed, and she was calm and contented.
Natásha said that she was not as before.
